item.title: U.S. Begins Stealth Bombing Runs Over South Korea
item.description: The rare announcement that the United States military ran a practice bombing sortie over South Korea underscores Washington’s commitment to defend its ally amid rising tensions with North Korea.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER and CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: The United States sent two long-range B-2 Spirit bombers over South Korea on Thursday.

item.title: Taliban Extending Reach Across Pakistan
item.description: The seaside city in Pakistan is no stranger to gangland violence as armed groups have battled over money, turf and votes.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH and ZIA ur-REHMAN
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shahi Syed of the Awami National Party in Pakistan said, “We are the Taliban’s first enemy.”

item.title: Iran, Syria and North Korea Stall Arms Treaty
item.description: The objections were at least a temporary setback for the treaty, the most ambitious attempt to regulate global trade in conventional weapons.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Political Divides Thwart Efforts to Form Government in Italy
item.description: An inconclusive election last month effectively split Parliament into three hostile fronts, making coalition-building an uphill struggle.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: The Lede: Palestinians Fight Prison Sentences for Mocking Their President on Facebook
item.description: For the second time in a month, a Palestinian court issued a one-year jail sentence to a West Bank resident convicted of insulting President Mahmoud Abbas on Facebook.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A composite image posted on Facebook compared the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, right, to a character from a Syrian historical drama who collaborated with the French colonial administration. The caption says the two men are "similar in every way."

item.title: U.N. Approves New Force to Pursue Congo’s Rebels
item.description: The United Nations Security Council authorized a new “intervention brigade” for the Democratic Republic of Congo, and gave it a mandate to carry out offensive operations.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Congolese refugees at a camp in South Kivu were displaced this month by clashes between rebels and Congolese Army troops.

item.title: American Ex-Soldier Charged With Aiding Terror Group
item.description: Eric Harroun, 30, of Phoenix, was charged on Thursday with fighting alongside a terrorist group that is battling the Syrian government of President Bashar al-Assad.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE

item.title: Damascus Students Killed in Mortar Strike
item.description: The blast from a mortar shell killed at least 10 people at Syria’s flagship Damascus University, where students had done their best to go about their business.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Syrian soldiers and investigators after a mortar killed at least 12 students on Thursday at a Damascus University cafe.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Bahrain: 21 Medics Cleared of Charges in 2011 Protests
item.description: A court in Bahrain on Thursday cleared 21 medics of charges linked to antigovernment protests in 2011, said a defense lawyer, Abdulla al-Shamlawi.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Opposition Activist’s Trial to Begin in April
item.description: The trial of the opposition activist Aleksei A. Navalny, who is accused of embezzling $500,000 from a timber company, will begin between April 15 and 19, court officials in Kirov now say.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Long Lines as Banks Reopen in Cyprus After Freeze
item.description: Relief that bank doors were open again mixed with anxiety over new rules that allow customers to make deposits but tightly ration out the money already in accounts.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: A Laiki Bank manager helped a police officer enter the bank after getting past waiting depositors on Thursday in Nicosia.

item.title: India Ink: 7 of 8 Ivy League Schools Report Lower Acceptance Rates
item.description: Harvard, Yale, Princeton, Cornell, Columbia, Brown and Penn were more selective when admitting the freshman class of 2013. If Dartmouth follows suit, all eight Ivy League institutions will have reported lower acceptance rates this year.
item.dc:creator: By TANYA ABRAMS

item.title: Baghdad Journal: For a Night at Least, Soccer Unites Iraqis and Syrians
item.description: On a pleasant spring evening, a week after car bombs killed dozens in the city, almost 50,000 Iraqis filled an old stadium to cheer as hard for the Syrian team as for their own players.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Employees from the Syrian embassy in Baghdad watched a game between Iraqi and Syrian national soccer teams.

item.title: India Ink: Newswallah: Bollywood and Organized Crime
item.description: A long history of links between the two.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI

item.title: New Border Tensions Erupt in Syrian Conflict
item.description: Turkey’s threat to prosecute or expel 130 refugees, and Israel’s growing concerns about injured Syrians coming across the border, are the latest signs of how Syria’s war has destabilized the region.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: India Ink: American Republicans Visit Modi in Gujarat
item.description: Three U.S. Congressional representatives met with the Gujarat chief minister in India Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By HARESH PANDYA
item.media:description: Gujarat Chief Minister Narendra Modi, center, meeting with a U.S. Congressional and business delegation in Gandhinagar, Gujarat, on Thursday.

item.title: Kenyan Panel Warns Against Nullifying Election
item.description: A besieged commission, accused of bungling presidential voting this month, said that nullifying it over a few irregularities would be a mistake.
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Easter Gets an Exemption From Spanish Austerity
item.description: Fund-raising for holiday celebrations underlines the clout of the Spanish Catholic Church, whose importance as a charitable institution has been enhanced by the country's economic crisis.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Myanmar’s Leader Says He May Use Force Over Rioting
item.description: President Thein Sein said he may resort to force to quell the religious rioting that has shaken his country.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: WORLD: Skiing Afghanistan
item.description: Bamian Province is the only place in Afghanistan that is actively promoting adventure tourism. Many residents lost what little they had under the Taliban and are wary about what the future might hold.

item.title: South Sudan Military Says 163 Killed in Clashes
item.description: A battle between South Sudan soldiers and rebels allegedly backed by neighboring Sudan killed 163 people, most of them rebels, government officials said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Fairy Circles in Africa May Be Work of Termites
item.description: New research posits that the reddish barren spots, known as fairy circles, that dot a narrow belt of African desert could be the work of industrious sand termites.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD
item.media:description: An aerial view of fairy circles — mysterious circular bare spots that new research suggests are created by termites.

item.title: Hong Kong Prepares for New Coronavirus
item.description: The city is among the first to become worried about the emergence and spread of another, genetically related virus in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Spring Delayed, Europe Shivers
item.description: Spring is yet to arrive in much of northern Europe. Experts say the prolonged cold is yet another extreme consequence of man-made climate change.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Farmers rescued a sheep in snowbound Northern Ireland on Tuesday.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: BRIC, BRICS or BRICSI? The Growing Challenge
item.description: Does BRICS increasingly challenge the world financial order as it forges more definite goals and measures, and is it a place to be for a strong Asian economy like Indonesia?
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The leaders of the BRICS countries, from left: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India, President Xi Jinping of China, President Jacob Zuma of South Africa, President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil and President Vladimir Putin of Russia, in Durban, South Africa.
